results.title: National velvet
results.brief_description: Based on the novel “National Velvet” by Enid Bagnold, this is the incredible story of a girl who rides to victory in the celebrated Grand National at Aintree, England. Velvet Brown, a young girl passionately interested in horses wins a horse in a raffle and with the help of Mi, an ex-jockey, sets out to win the greatest steeplechase in the world, the Grand National. Stars Elizabeth Taylor and Mickey Rooney. Rated: G

results.title: National Ranger 505 Transistor TV
results.creator_credit: Matsushita Electrical Co. Ltd. and National Panasonic
results.creator_credit_for_label: Matsushita Electrical Co. Ltd. and National Panasonic
results.description:
National Ranger 505 Transistor TV is a portable TV with handle, small screen and folding antennae. The television was completely portable - it could be powered with either mains power or batteries, allowing the user to kick back and take the TV to the beach, campground or backyard.

National was a brand used by Panasonic Corporation sell home appliances, personal appliances, and industrial appliances. The National brand operated in Australia until 1988 when it transferred to The Panasonic Corporation.

results.title: National Portable Video Camera WV-3085
results.brief_description: The Portapak system is a handheld video camera with separate reel-to-reel video recorder. It enabled videos to be captured and played back more quickly while also cutting down on the cost, which led to the birth of video art, guerrilla television and activism.

constellations_primary.name: Access to resistance
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

results.description: The Portapak system consists of a handheld video camera with a separate reel-to-reel video recorder in a portable pack that could be carried over the shoulder. The style was first released by Sony in 1967 and was an important development in camera technology, enabling a new level of portability with both the camera and recorder battery-powered and self-contained. It enabled videos to be captured and played back more quickly while also cutting down on the cost, which led to the birth of video art, guerrilla television and activism. In the 1970s, the Portapak was popular with video artists and alternative media collectives. In Australia, Open Channel and the Paddington Video Access Centre used Portapaks to create alternative broadcast channels, paving the way for community television.
description_for_label: The Portapak system consists of a handheld video camera with a separate reel-to-reel video recorder in a portable pack that could be carried over the shoulder. The style was first released by Sony in 1967 and was an important development in camera technology, enabling a new level of portability with both the camera and recorder battery-powered and self-contained. It enabled videos to be captured and played back more quickly while also cutting down on the cost, which led to the birth of video art, guerrilla television and activism. In the 1970s, the Portapak was popular with video artists and alternative media collectives. In Australia, Open Channel and the Paddington Video Access Centre used Portapaks to create alternative broadcast channels, paving the way for community television.

results.title: National income and economic policy: the supply of money
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Open University and Peter Ramsden
results.brief_description: This program describes in some detail money supply and the institutions which are concerned in it; it also examinesa the various constraints which make the control of the money supply a difficult matter. The program was made in early 1972, before the monetary system had adapted itself completely to the new arrangements introduced by the Bank of England in late 1971.

results.title: National Geographic: beyond the movie. "The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the ring"
results.creator_credit: National Geographic Television and Kathleen Phelan
results.brief_description: Peter Jackson’s “Lord of the rings” trilogy brought the world of Tolkien’s Middle Earth to the big screen and gave visual presence to an era familiar to a legion of fans. This presentation from “National Geographic” seeks to find the inspiration and influences behind Tolkien’s work and the relevance of the quest today. Issues covered include the origins of the Elvish language and the race of hobbits, the impact of mass industrialization to the detriment of the environment, the onset of World War I, and Anglo-Saxon culture as presented in “Beowulf” on Tolkien’s writing. Includes interviews with cast members, director Peter Jackson, publisher and personal friend of Tolkien, Ray Unwin, historians and archaeologists, and location scouts for the film who provide fascinating details about re-creating Middle Earth. Narrated by Phil Crowley.

results.title: National Folk Festival. Part 3
results.brief_description: Shows scenes of folk dances performed at the National Folk festival in St Louis. Includes examples of Israelii, Russian, Czechoslovakian, and American square dances, and Ozark ballads, songs of the Pennsylvanian coal minders, Spanish and American songs and “Casey Jones”.

results.title: National Folk Festival. Part 2
results.brief_description: Shows scenes of folk dances performed at the National Folk festival in St Louis. The film includes Polish, English, Croatian, American Indian, Lithuanian, Ukrainian, Texas and Tennessee dances together with African American and Yugoslav songs.
